newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL blue chips end weaker, autos still in doldrums.
newsitem.headline: KL blue chips end weaker, autos still in doldrums.

text.p: Continued weakness in auto stocks and a selloff in a handful of small-capitalisation issues by speculators brought Kuala Lumpur shares to a sharply lower finish after a thinly-traded Wednesday, dealers said.
"No positive news is coming out as yet," said Ami Moris, a vice president in dealing at Capitalcorp. "Blue chips are getting hammered on rotation, and now it's motor stocks."
Fears a strong yen will raise import costs for car companies have driven their stock prices lower. The blue chip-focused Composite Index ended down 12.06 points or 1.11 percent to 1,072.49.

Stocks related to automaker Proton Bhd appeared to take little comfort from Proton chairman Saleh Sulong's statement that the company has not so far been hurt by the rising yen. He also said Proton has made forward purchases of the Japanese currency.
Proton shares were down 60 cents to 12.90 ringgit. Parent companies Hicom Holdings lost eight cents to 4.90 while Diversified Resources Bhd fell five to 5.70.
Elsewhere in the group, Gadek Malaysia Bhd lost 60 cents to 13.20, while Edaran Otomobil Nasional Bhd shed 40 cents to 23.50 ringgit.
